title: Bigalora expansions include Detroit
text:
Chef Luciano DelSignore is working on four Bigalora-branded restaurant projects simultaneously, including two in Detroit's Midtown. Chef Luciano DelSignore is finally bringing his wood-fired Bigalora Italian food to Detroit — but not yet in a full-scale Bigalora restaurant. 
Instead, he and his business partners will open a panini pop-up — likely next week — in the Shinola watch and bike store in Midtown, followed in late December or January by a Bigalora pizza and grab-and-go concept in the Detroit Medical Center. 
They’re among four Bigalora-branded projects DelSignore and his partners have in simultaneous development across metro Detroit. "We've been busy," he says. 
Besides the two Detroit projects, they’re also opening full-scale restaurants in Rochester Hills and in the McNamara Terminal at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. 
DelSignore has Bigaloras in Southfield, Royal Oak and Ann Arbor, featuring thin-crust pizzas fired in 90 seconds in imported Italian wood-fired ovens, as well as pastas, salads, small plates and wood-roasted meats, fish and other dishes. Grille Midtown reinvents itself with new name, menu 
The Shinola pop-up will start simply, partner Michael Chetcuti said, offering six wrapped-and-ready cold sandwiches in a display case at the store’s sales terminals. They’ll be prepared at Bigalora using DelSignore’s recipes, so the first phase — set to begin mid-next week — will require no additional employees or cooking at Shinola. 
If that goes well, Chetcuti says, the next step might have Shinola employees toasting the already-assembled panini so customers could have hot sandwiches. 
DelSignore said the idea came about because Shinola’s owners wanted healthier food options in the neighborhood. The sandwiches they’ll offer include two vegan and two vegetarian options, and the breads will be made with the all-natural biga starter used in Bigalora’s pizza dough. 
The much more ambitious project at Detroit Medical Center could be open by late December or early January, DelSignore said. 
It’s part of a major renovation that will create a new front entrance for the DMC campus, DelSignore said, and turn the entire first floor of the area into a food destination with concepts from three highly regarded vendors. 
DMC has announced it is building a new entrance at Hutzel Hospital, but a spokesperson declined to discuss other details about the project, which is still in the final stages of development. 
On one side of the dining area will be a Mexican concept called Chiqui (Spanish slang for "little brother"), opened by Adam Baru, owner of Ann Arbor’s Isalita and Mani Osteria restaurants, and his brother, Michael Baru. Papa Joe’s Gourmet Markets, the high-end grocer and caterer known for its prepared foods in Birmingham and Rochester Hills, will occupy the larger, middle section, DelSignore said. 
And on the other side of the dining space, opposite Chiqui, Bigalora will have a 1,500-square-foot free-standing concept, “almost like our own little building,” where customers can see their pizzas being fired in 90 seconds and select from a wide variety of grab-and-go items, DelSignore said. He will also offer fresh pastas and probably sandwiches and panini. 
All three restaurateurs hope to open at the same time, he said. “When we open, we want to open with a bang.” Farmington Hills woman opens Detroit breakfast cafe 
The new Rochester Hills Bigalora will occupy the large restaurant space that previously was the Hill, at the end of the L-shaped shopping area anchored by Papa Joe’s, north of downtown Rochester. The renovation is in the final stages of design with a target opening date of February. 
The 160-seat McNamara Terminal restaurant, set in a prime location at the bottom of the escalator just past security, should be open by Thanksgiving, DelSignore said. It will have a full Bigalora menu of pizzas fired in 90 seconds, pastas, grab-and-go items, desserts, panini and Bigalora’s full brunch menu, since the restaurant will serve breakfast daily. 
Strictly speaking, the pop-up and DMC locations won’t be Bigalora’s first foray into Detroit, since it has club-level service at Ford Field. But that’s accessible to a relatively tiny audience. 
Asked when Bigalora might bring the city a full-scale Bigalora, Chetcuti wouldn’t offer a date and would only say, "It's on the short list.” 
But DelSignore eliminated any remaining doubt: “Bricks-and-mortar is inevitable in Detroit. It's inevitable," he said.
